**Asbestos** is a set of six naturally occurring [silicate
minerals](/wiki/Silicate_minerals "Silicate minerals"),[1] which all have in
common their [eponymous](/wiki/Eponymous "Eponymous")
[asbestiform](/wiki/Asbestiform "Asbestiform") [habit](/wiki/Crystal_habit
"Crystal habit"): i.e. long (roughly 1:20 [aspect ratio](/wiki/Aspect_ratio
"Aspect ratio")), thin [fibrous](/wiki/Fibrous "Fibrous")
[crystals](/wiki/Crystal "Crystal"), with each visible fiber composed of
millions of microscopic "fibrils" that can be released by
[abrasion](/wiki/Abrasion_\(mechanical\) "Abrasion \(mechanical\)") and other
processes.[2] They are commonly known by their colors, as _blue asbestos_ ,
_brown asbestos_ , _white asbestos_ , and _green asbestos_.[3]

Asbestos mining existed more than 4,000 years ago, but large-scale mining
began at the end of the 19th century, when manufacturers and builders began
using asbestos for its desirable physical properties.[1] Some of those
properties are [sound absorption](/wiki/Absorption_\(acoustics\) "Absorption
\(acoustics\)"), average [tensile strength](/wiki/Tensile_strength "Tensile
strength"), affordability, and [resistance to fire](/wiki/Flame-retardant
"Flame-retardant"), heat, and electricity. It was used in such applications as
[electrical insulation](/wiki/Electrical_insulation "Electrical insulation")
for hotplate wiring and in [building insulation](/wiki/Building_insulation
"Building insulation"). When asbestos is used for its resistance to fire or
heat, the fibers are often mixed with cement or woven into fabric or mats.
These desirable properties made asbestos very widely used. Asbestos use
continued to grow through most of the 20th century until public knowledge
(acting through courts and legislatures) of the health hazards of asbestos
dust outlawed asbestos in mainstream construction and
[fireproofing](/wiki/Fireproofing "Fireproofing") in most countries.

[Inhalation](/wiki/Inhalation "Inhalation") of asbestos fibers can cause
serious and fatal illnesses including [lung cancer](/wiki/Lung_cancer "Lung
cancer"), [mesothelioma](/wiki/Mesothelioma "Mesothelioma"), and
[asbestosis](/wiki/Asbestosis "Asbestosis") (a type of
[pneumoconiosis](/wiki/Pneumoconiosis "Pneumoconiosis")).[4][5] Concern of
asbestos-related illness in modern times began with the 20th century and
escalated during the 1920s and 1930s. By the 1980s and 1990s, asbestos trade
and use were heavily restricted, phased out, or banned outright in an
increasing number of countries.[6]

Despite the severity of asbestos-related diseases, the material has extremely
widespread use in many areas. Continuing long-term use of asbestos after
harmful health effects were known or suspected, and the slow emergence of
symptoms decades after exposure ceased, made [asbestos
litigation](/wiki/Asbestos_and_the_law "Asbestos and the law") the longest,
most expensive mass [tort](/wiki/Tort "Tort") in U.S. history and a much
lesser legal issue in most other countries involved.[7] Asbestos-related
[liability](/wiki/Legal_liability "Legal liability") also remains an ongoing
concern for many manufacturers, [insurers and
reinsurers](/wiki/Insurance_industry "Insurance industry").

## Etymology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Asbestos&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Etymology")]

Asbestos derives from the [ancient Greek](/wiki/Ancient_Greece "Ancient
Greece") ἄσβεστος, meaning unquenchable or inextinguishable.[1][8][9] The word
is pronounced [/æsˈbɛstəs/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English"),
[/æzˈbɛstəs/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") or
[/æzˈbɛstɒs/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English").

## Types and associated
fibers[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Asbestos&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section:
Types and associated fibers")]

Six mineral types are defined by the [United States Environmental Protection
Agency](/wiki/United_States_Environmental_Protection_Agency "United States
Environmental Protection Agency") (EPA) as "asbestos" including those
belonging to the [serpentine](/wiki/Serpentine_subgroup "Serpentine subgroup")
class and those belonging to the amphibole class. All six asbestos mineral
types are known to be human [carcinogens](/wiki/Carcinogens
"Carcinogens").[10][11] The visible fibers are themselves each composed of
millions of microscopic "fibrils" that can be released by
[abrasion](/wiki/Abrasion_\(mechanical\) "Abrasion \(mechanical\)") and other
processes.[2]

### Serpentine[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Asbestos&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Serpentine")]

Serpentine class fibers are curly. [Chrysotile](/wiki/Chrysotile "Chrysotile")
is the only member of the serpentine class.

#### Chrysotile[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Asbestos&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Chrysotile")]

[Chrysotile](/wiki/Chrysotile "Chrysotile"), [CAS
No.](/wiki/CAS_registry_number "CAS registry number") 12001-29-5, is obtained
from [serpentinite](/wiki/Serpentinite "Serpentinite") rocks which are common
throughout the world. Its idealized [chemical formula](/wiki/Chemical_formula
"Chemical formula") is [Mg](/wiki/Magnesium "Magnesium")3([Si](/wiki/Silicon
"Silicon")2[O](/wiki/Oxygen "Oxygen")5)([OH](/wiki/Hydroxide
"Hydroxide"))4.[12] Chrysotile appears under the microscope as a white fiber.

Chrysotile has been used more than any other type and accounts for about 95%
of the asbestos found in buildings in America.[13] Chrysotile is more flexible
than amphibole types of asbestos, and can be spun and woven into fabric. The
most common use was corrugated asbestos cement roofing primarily for
outbuildings, warehouses and garages. It may also be found in sheets or panels
used for ceilings and sometimes for walls and floors. Chrysotile has been a
component in [joint compound](/wiki/Joint_compound "Joint compound") and some
plasters. Numerous other items have been made containing chrysotile including
brake linings, fire barriers in fuseboxes, pipe insulation, floor tiles,
residential shingles, and gaskets for high temperature equipment.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Amphibole[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Asbestos&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Amphibole")]

Amphibole class fibers are needle-like. [Amosite](/wiki/Amosite "Amosite"),
[crocidolite](/wiki/Crocidolite "Crocidolite"), [tremolite](/wiki/Tremolite
"Tremolite"), [anthophyllite](/wiki/Anthophyllite "Anthophyllite") and
[actinolite](/wiki/Actinolite "Actinolite") are members of the amphibole
class.

#### Amosite[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Asbestos&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Amosite")]

[Amosite](/wiki/Amosite "Amosite"), CAS No. 12172-73-5, often referred to as
brown asbestos, is a [trade name](/wiki/Trade_name "Trade name") for the
amphiboles belonging to the [cummingtonite](/wiki/Cummingtonite
"Cummingtonite")-[grunerite](/wiki/Grunerite "Grunerite") [solid
solution](/wiki/Solid_solution "Solid solution") series, commonly from South
Africa, named as a partial [acronym](/wiki/Acronym "Acronym") for "Asbestos
Mines of South Africa". One formula given for amosite is [Fe](/wiki/Iron
"Iron")7Si8O22(OH)2. Amosite is seen under a microscope as a grey-white
vitreous fiber. It is found most frequently as a fire retardant in thermal
insulation products, [asbestos insulating
board](/wiki/Asbestos_insulating_board "Asbestos insulating board") and
ceiling tiles.[13]

#### Crocidolite[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Asbestos&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Crocidolite")]

[Crocidolite](/wiki/Crocidolite "Crocidolite"), CAS No. 12001-28-4, is the
fibrous form of the amphibole [riebeckite](/wiki/Riebeckite "Riebeckite"),
found primarily in southern Africa, but also in Australia and Bolivia. One
formula given for crocidolite is [Na](/wiki/Sodium
"Sodium")2Fe2+3Fe3+2Si8O22([OH](/wiki/Hydroxyl "Hydroxyl"))2. Crocidolite is
seen under a microscope as a blue fiber.

[Crocidolite](/wiki/Crocidolite "Crocidolite") commonly occurs as soft
[friable](/wiki/Friability "Friability") fibers. Asbestiform amphibole may
also occur as soft friable fibers but some varieties such as amosite are
commonly straighter. All forms of asbestos are fibrillar in that they are
composed of fibers with breadths less than 1 [micrometer](/wiki/Micrometre
"Micrometre") in bundles of very great widths. Asbestos with particularly fine
fibers is also referred to as "amianthus".

#### Other materials[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Asbestos&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Other materials")]

Other regulated asbestos minerals, such as tremolite asbestos, CAS No.
77536-68-6, [Ca](/wiki/Calcium "Calcium")2Mg5Si8O22(OH)2; actinolite asbestos,
CAS No. 77536-66-4, Ca2(Mg, Fe)5(Si8O22)(OH)2; and anthophyllite asbestos, CAS
No. 77536-67-5, (Mg, Fe)7Si8O22(OH)2; are less commonly used industrially but
can still be found in a variety of construction materials and insulation
materials and have been used in a few [consumer
products](/wiki/Product_\(business\) "Product \(business\)").

Other natural asbestiform minerals, such as [richterite](/wiki/Richterite
"Richterite"), Na(CaNa)(Mg, Fe++)5(Si8O22)(OH)2, and
[winchite](/w/index.php?title=Winchite&action=edit&redlink=1 "Winchite \(page
does not exist\)"), (CaNa)Mg4(Al, Fe3+)(Si8O22)(OH)2, though not regulated,
are said by some to be no less harmful than tremolite, amosite, or
crocidolite.[14] They are termed "asbestiform" rather than asbestos. Although
the U.S. [Occupational Safety and Health
Administration](/wiki/Occupational_Safety_and_Health_Administration
"Occupational Safety and Health Administration") (OSHA) has not included them
in the asbestos standard, NIOSH and the American Thoracic Society have
recommended them for inclusion as regulated materials because they may also be
hazardous to health.[14]

## Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Asbestos&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Production")]

In 2009, about 9% of world's asbestos production was mined in Canada.[15] In
late 2011, Canada's remaining two asbestos mines, both located in the
[Province of Quebec](/wiki/Province_of_Quebec "Province of Quebec"), halted
operations.[16] In September 2012, the government in the Province of Quebec
halted asbestos mining.[17]

In 2015, 2 million [tonnes](/wiki/Tonne "Tonne") of asbestos were mined
worldwide. The Russian Federation was the largest producer with about 55%
world share followed by China (20%), Brazil (15.6%), and Kazakhstan
(10.8%).[18]

### Early uses[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Asbestos&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Early uses")]

Asbestos use dates back at least 4,500 years, when the inhabitants of the Lake
[Juojärvi](/wiki/Juoj%C3%A4rvi "Juojärvi") region in East
[Finland](/wiki/Finland "Finland") strengthened earthenware pots and cooking
utensils with the asbestos mineral anthophyllite (see [Asbestos-
ceramic](/wiki/Asbestos-ceramic "Asbestos-ceramic")).[19] One of the first
descriptions of a material that may have been asbestos is in
[Theophrastus](/wiki/Theophrastus "Theophrastus"), _On Stones_ , from around
300 BC, although this identification has been questioned.[20] In both modern
and ancient [Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language"), the usual name for
the material known in English as "asbestos" is _amiantos_ ("undefiled",
"pure"), which was adapted into the French _amiante_ and Portuguese _amianto_.
In [modern Greek](/wiki/Modern_Greek "Modern Greek"), the word ἀσβεστος or
ασβέστης stands consistently and solely for [lime](/wiki/Lime_\(mineral\)
"Lime \(mineral\)").

The term _asbestos_ is traceable to Roman naturalist [Pliny the
Elder](/wiki/Pliny_the_Elder "Pliny the Elder")'s manuscript _[Natural
History](/wiki/Natural_History_\(Pliny\) "Natural History \(Pliny\)")_ , and
his use of the term _asbestinon_ , meaning "unquenchable".[1][8][19] While
Pliny or his nephew [Pliny the Younger](/wiki/Pliny_the_Younger "Pliny the
Younger") is popularly credited with recognising the detrimental effects of
asbestos on human beings,[21] examination of the primary sources reveals no
support for either claim.[22]

Wealthy [Persians](/wiki/Persian_people "Persian people") amazed guests by
cleaning a cloth by exposing it to fire. For example, according to
[Tabari](/wiki/Muhammad_ibn_Jarir_al-Tabari "Muhammad ibn Jarir al-Tabari"),
one of the curious items belonging to [Khosrow II](/wiki/Khosrow_II "Khosrow
II") Parviz, the great [Sassanian](/wiki/Sassanian "Sassanian") king (r.
531–579), was a napkin ([Persian](/wiki/Persian_language "Persian language"):
منديل‎) that he cleaned simply by throwing it into fire. Such cloth is
believed to have been made of asbestos imported over the [Hindu
Kush](/wiki/Hindu_Kush "Hindu Kush").[23] According to
[Biruni](/wiki/Biruni#ref-16 "Biruni") in his book, _Gems_ , any cloths made
of asbestos ([Persian](/wiki/Persian_language "Persian language"): آذرشست‎,
_āzarshost_) were called _shostakeh_ ([Persian](/wiki/Persian_language
"Persian language"): شستكه‎).[24] Some Persians believed the fiber was the fur
of an animal, called the _[samandar](/wiki/Salamander_\(legendary_creature\)
"Salamander \(legendary creature\)")_ ([Persian](/wiki/Persian_language
"Persian language"): سمندر‎), which lived in fire and died when exposed to
water,[25][26] which was where the former belief that the
[salamander](/wiki/Salamander "Salamander") could tolerate fire
originated.[27]

[Charlemagne](/wiki/Charlemagne "Charlemagne"), the first [Holy Roman
Emperor](/wiki/Holy_Roman_Emperor "Holy Roman Emperor") (800–814), is said to
have had a tablecloth made of asbestos.[28]

[Marco Polo](/wiki/Marco_Polo "Marco Polo") recounts having been shown, in a
place he calls _Ghinghin talas_ , "a good vein from which the cloth which we
call of salamander, which cannot be burnt if it is thrown into the fire, is
made ..."[29]

Some archaeologists believe that ancients made shrouds of asbestos, wherein
they burned the bodies of their kings, in order to preserve only their ashes,
and prevent them being mixed with those of wood or other combustible materials
commonly used in funeral pyres.[30][31] Others assert that the ancients used
asbestos to make perpetual wicks for [sepulchral](/wiki/Sepulchre "Sepulchre")
or other lamps.[25] A famous example is the golden lamp _asbestos lychnis_ ,
which the sculptor [Callimachus](/wiki/Callimachus_\(sculptor\) "Callimachus
\(sculptor\)") made for the [Erechtheion](/wiki/Erechtheion
"Erechtheion").[32] In more recent centuries, asbestos was indeed used for
this purpose. Although asbestos causes skin to itch upon contact, [ancient
literature](/wiki/Ancient_literature "Ancient literature") indicates that it
was prescribed for diseases of the skin, and particularly for the itch. It is
possible that they used the term _asbestos_ for [soapstone](/wiki/Soapstone
"Soapstone"), because the two terms have often been confused throughout
history.[30][_[page needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing
sources")_]

### Industrial era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Asbestos&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Industrial era")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/d/de/Asbestos_mining_1876.jpg/220px-
Asbestos_mining_1876.jpg)](/wiki/File:Asbestos_mining_1876.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Asbestos_mining_1876.jpg "Enlarge")

Industrial scale asbestos mining began in 1878 in [Thetford
township](/wiki/Thetford_Mines "Thetford Mines"), [Quebec](/wiki/Quebec
"Quebec"). By 1895, mining was increasingly mechanized.

The large scale asbestos industry began in the mid-19th century. Early
attempts at producing asbestos paper and cloth in Italy began in the 1850s,
but were unsuccessful in creating a market for such products. Canadian samples
of asbestos were displayed in London in 1862, and the first companies were
formed in England and Scotland to exploit this resource. Asbestos was first
used in the manufacture of yarn, and German industrialist Louis Wertheim
adopted this process in his factories in Germany. [33] In 1871, the Patent
Asbestos Manufacturing Company was established in Glasgow, and within the
following decades, the [Clydebank](/wiki/Clydebank "Clydebank") area became a
centre for the nascent industry.[34]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Asbestos%2C_Quebec%2C_Canada.jpg/220px-
Asbestos%2C_Quebec%2C_Canada.jpg)](/wiki/File:Asbestos,_Quebec,_Canada.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Asbestos,_Quebec,_Canada.jpg "Enlarge")

Canada's biggest power shovel loading an ore train with asbestos at the
Jeffrey Mine, Johns-Manville Co., Asbestos, Quebec, June 1944.

Industrial scale mining began in the [Thetford hills](/wiki/Thetford_Mines
"Thetford Mines"), [Quebec](/wiki/Quebec "Quebec") from the 1870s. Sir
[William Edmond Logan](/wiki/William_Edmond_Logan "William Edmond Logan") was
the first to notice the large deposits of [chrysotile](/wiki/Chrysotile
"Chrysotile") in the hills in his capacity as head of [Geological Survey of
Canada](/wiki/Geological_Survey_of_Canada "Geological Survey of Canada").
Samples of the minerals from here were displayed in London, and excited much
interest.[33] With the opening up of the [Quebec Central
Railway](/wiki/Quebec_Central_Railway "Quebec Central Railway") in 1876,
mining entrepreneurs, such as [Andrew Stuart
Johnson](/wiki/Andrew_Stuart_Johnson "Andrew Stuart Johnson") established the
asbestos industry in the province.[35] The 50 ton output of the mines in 1878
rose to over 10,000 tons in the 1890s with the adoption of machine
technologies and expanded production.[33][36] For a long time, the world's
largest asbestos mine was the Jeffrey mine in the town of [Asbestos,
Quebec](/wiki/Asbestos,_Quebec "Asbestos, Quebec").[37]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Asbestos_iron_ad.jpg/220px-
Asbestos_iron_ad.jpg)](/wiki/File:Asbestos_iron_ad.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Asbestos_iron_ad.jpg "Enlarge")

The applications of asbestos multiplied at the end of the 19th century. This
is an advertisement for an asbestos-lined [clothes iron](/wiki/Clothes_iron
"Clothes iron") from 1906.

Asbestos production began in the [Urals](/wiki/Urals "Urals") of the [Russian
Empire](/wiki/Russian_Empire "Russian Empire") in the 1880s, and in the
[Alpine regions](/wiki/Alps "Alps") of [Northern Italy](/wiki/Northern_Italy
"Northern Italy") with the formation in [Turin](/wiki/Turin "Turin") of the
Italo-English Pure Asbestos Company in 1876, although this was soon swamped by
the greater production levels from the Canadian mines. Mining also took off in
[South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa") from 1893 under the aegis of
the British businessman Francis Oates, the Director of the [De
Beers](/wiki/De_Beers "De Beers") company.[38] It was in South Africa that the
production of amosite began in 1910. The U.S. asbestos industry had an early
start in 1858, when fibrous anthophyllite was mined for use as asbestos
insulation by the Johns Company, a predecessor to the current Johns Manville,
at a quarry at Ward's Hill on Staten Island, New York.[39] US production began
in earnest in 1899, with the discovery of large deposits in the [Belvidere
Mountain](/wiki/Eden,_Vermont#Belvidere_Mountain "Eden, Vermont").

The use of asbestos became increasingly widespread towards the end of the 19th
century, when its diverse applications included fire retardant coatings,
concrete, bricks, pipes and fireplace cement, heat, fire, and acid resistant
gaskets, pipe insulation, ceiling insulation, fireproof drywall, flooring,
roofing, lawn furniture, and drywall joint compound. In 2011 it was reported
that over 50% of UK houses still contained asbestos, despite a ban on asbestos
products some years earlier.[40]

In Japan, particularly after [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War
II"), asbestos was used in the manufacture of [ammonium
sulfate](/wiki/Ammonium_sulfate "Ammonium sulfate") for purposes of rice
production, sprayed upon the ceilings, iron skeletons, and walls of railroad
cars and buildings (during the 1960s), and used for energy efficiency reasons
as well. Production of asbestos in Japan peaked in 1974 and went through ups
and downs until about 1990, when production began to drop dramatically.[41]

section: Discovery of toxicity")]

For additional chronological citations, see [List of asbestos disease medical
articles](/wiki/List_of_asbestos_disease_medical_articles "List of asbestos
disease medical articles").

In 1899, Montague Murray noted the negative health effects of asbestos.[42]
The first documented death related to asbestos was in 1906.[43]

In the early 1900s researchers began to notice a large number of early deaths
and lung problems in asbestos-mining towns. The first such study was conducted
by H. Montague Murray at the [Charing Cross
Hospital](/wiki/Charing_Cross_Hospital "Charing Cross Hospital"),
[London](/wiki/London "London"), in 1900, in which a postmortem investigation
of a young man who had died from [pulmonary fibrosis](/wiki/Pulmonary_fibrosis
"Pulmonary fibrosis") after having worked for 14 years in an asbestos textile
factory, discovered asbestos traces in the victim's lungs. [Adelaide
Anderson](/wiki/Adelaide_Anderson "Adelaide Anderson"), the Inspector of
Factories in Britain, included asbestos in a list of harmful industrial
substances in 1902. Similar investigations were conducted in France and Italy,
in 1906 and 1908, respectively.[44]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Heat-
resistant_asbestos_fabric.jpg/220px-Heat-
resistant_asbestos_fabric.jpg)](/wiki/File:Heat-resistant_asbestos_fabric.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Heat-resistant_asbestos_fabric.jpg "Enlarge")

Asbestos fabric

The first diagnosis of asbestosis was made in the UK in 1924.[43][45][46]
[Nellie Kershaw](/wiki/Nellie_Kershaw "Nellie Kershaw") was employed at
[Turner Brothers Asbestos](/wiki/Turner_%26_Newall "Turner & Newall") in
[Manchester](/wiki/Manchester "Manchester"), [England](/wiki/England
"England") from 1917, spinning raw asbestos fibre into yarn.[46][47] Her death
in 1924 led to a formal inquest. [Pathologist](/wiki/Pathology "Pathology")
William Edmund Cooke testified that his examination of the lungs indicated old
scarring indicative of a previous, healed, tuberculosis infection, and
extensive [fibrosis](/wiki/Fibrosis "Fibrosis"), in which were visible
"particles of mineral matter ... of various shapes, but the large majority
have sharp angles."[45] Having compared these particles with samples of
asbestos dust provided by S. A. Henry, His Majesty's Medical Inspector of
Factories, Cooke concluded that they "originated from asbestos and were,
beyond a reasonable doubt, the primary cause of the fibrosis of the lungs and
therefore of death".[46][48]

As a result of Cooke's paper,
[parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom "Parliament of the United
Kingdom") commissioned an inquiry into the effects of asbestos dust by E. R.
A. Merewether, Medical Inspector of Factories, and C. W. Price, a [factory
inspector](/wiki/History_of_labour_law_in_the_United_Kingdom#Factory_and_Workshop_Act_1901
"History of labour law in the United Kingdom") and pioneer of dust monitoring
and control.[2] Their subsequent report, _Occurrence of Pulmonary Fibrosis &
Other Pulmonary Affections in Asbestos Workers_, was presented to parliament
on 24 March 1930.[49] It concluded that the development of asbestosis was
irrefutably linked to the prolonged inhalation of asbestos dust, and included
the first health study of asbestos workers, which found that 66% of those
employed for 20 years or more suffered from asbestosis.[2] The report led to
the publication of the first Asbestos Industry Regulations in 1931, which came
into effect on 1 March 1932.[50] These regulated ventilation and made
[asbestosis](/wiki/Asbestosis "Asbestosis") an excusable work-related
disease.[12] The term [mesothelioma](/wiki/Mesothelioma "Mesothelioma") was
first used in medical literature in 1931; its association with asbestos was
first noted sometime in the 1940s. Similar legislation followed in the U.S.
about ten years later.

Approximately 100,000 people in the United States have died, or are terminally
ill, from asbestos exposure related to ship building. In the [Hampton
Roads](/wiki/Hampton_Roads "Hampton Roads") area, a shipbuilding center,
mesothelioma occurrence is seven times the national rate.[51] Thousands of
tons of asbestos were used in World War II ships to insulate piping, boilers,
steam engines, and steam turbines. There were approximately 4.3 million
shipyard workers in the United States during WWII; for every 1,000 workers
about 14 died of mesothelioma and an unknown number died from asbestosis.[52]

The United States government and asbestos industry have been criticized for
not acting quickly enough to inform the public of dangers, and to reduce
public exposure. In the late 1970s, court documents proved that asbestos
industry officials knew of asbestos dangers since the 1930s and had concealed
them from the public.[52]

In Australia, asbestos was widely used in construction and other industries
between 1946 and 1980. From the 1970s there was increasing concern about the
dangers of asbestos, and its use was phased out. Mining ceased in 1983. The
use of asbestos was phased out in 1989 and banned entirely in December 2003.
The dangers of asbestos are now well known in Australia and there is help and
support for sufferers from asbestosis or mesothelioma.[53]

#### Serpentine
group[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Asbestos&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section:
Serpentine group")]

Serpentine minerals have a sheet or layered structure. Chrysotile is the only
asbestos mineral in the serpentine group. In the United States, chrysotile has
been the most commonly used type of asbestos. According to the U.S. EPA
Asbestos Building Inspectors Manual, chrysotile accounts for approximately 95%
of asbestos found in buildings in the United States.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
Chrysotile is often present in a wide variety of products and materials,
including:

  * Chlor Alkali diaphragm membranes [used to make chlorine](/wiki/Chloralkali_process "Chloralkali process") (currently in the USA) [54]
  * [Drywall](/wiki/Drywall "Drywall") and joint compound (including texture coats)
  * [Plaster](/wiki/Plaster "Plaster")
  * Gas mask filters pre-1960s and gas mask filters from the USSR
  * Vinyl floor tiles, sheeting, adhesives
  * Roofing tars, felts, siding, and shingles[55]
  * "[Transite](/wiki/Transite "Transite")" panels, siding, countertops, and pipes
  * [Popcorn ceilings](/wiki/Popcorn_ceiling "Popcorn ceiling"), also known as acoustic ceilings
  * [Fireproofing](/wiki/Fireproofing "Fireproofing")

#### Amphibole group[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Asbestos&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Amphibole group")]

Amphiboles including [amosite](/wiki/Amosite "Amosite") (brown asbestos) and
[crocidolite](/wiki/Crocidolite "Crocidolite") (blue asbestos) were formerly
used in many products until the early 1980s.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
[Tremolite](/wiki/Tremolite "Tremolite") asbestos constituted a contaminant of
many if not all naturally occurring chrysotile deposits. The use of all types
of asbestos in the amphibole group was banned in much of the Western world by
the mid-1980s, and in Japan by 1995.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Some
products that included amphibole types of asbestos included the following:

  * Low density insulating board (often referred to as AIB or asbestos insulating board) and ceiling tiles;
  * Asbestos-cement pipe (made until the early 1990s by at least one manufacturer);
  * [Asbestos-cement](/wiki/Eternit "Eternit") sheets and pipes for construction, casing for water and electrical/telecommunication services;
  * Thermal and chemical insulation (e.g., fire rated doors, limpet spray, lagging and gaskets).

Cigarette manufacturer [Lorillard](/wiki/Lorillard "Lorillard")
([Kent's](/wiki/Kent_\(cigarette\) "Kent \(cigarette\)") [filtered
cigarette](/wiki/Cigarette_filter "Cigarette filter")) used crocidolite
asbestos in its "Micronite" filter from 1952 to 1956.[57]

While mostly chrysotile asbestos fibers were once used in automobile [brake
pads](/wiki/Brake_pads "Brake pads"), shoes, and [clutch discs](/wiki/Clutch
"Clutch"), contaminants of amphiboles were present. Since approximately the
mid-1990s, brake pads, new or replacement, have been manufactured instead with
linings made of ceramic, carbon, metallic and [aramid fiber](/wiki/Aramid
"Aramid") ([Twaron](/wiki/Twaron "Twaron") or [Kevlar](/wiki/Kevlar
"Kevlar")—the same material used in [bulletproof vests](/wiki/Bulletproof_vest
"Bulletproof vest")).

Artificial Christmas snow, known as flocking, was previously made with
asbestos.[58] It was used as an effect in films including _[The Wizard of
Oz](/wiki/The_Wizard_of_Oz_\(1939_film\) "The Wizard of Oz \(1939 film\)")_
and department store window displays and it was marketed for use in private
homes under brand names that included "Pure White", "Snow Drift" and "White
Magic".[59]

The use of asbestos in new construction projects has been banned for health
and safety reasons in many developed countries or regions, including the
European Union, Australia, Hong Kong, Japan, and New Zealand. A notable
exception is the United States, where asbestos continues to be used in
construction such as cement asbestos pipes. The 5th Circuit Court prevented
the EPA from banning asbestos in 1991 because EPA research showed the ban
would cost between $450 and 800 million while only saving around 200 lives in
a 13-year timeframe, and that the EPA did not provide adequate evidence for
the safety of alternative products.[60] Until the mid-1980s, small amounts of
white asbestos were used in the manufacture of [Artex](/wiki/Artex "Artex"), a
decorative stipple finish,[61] however, some of the lesser-known suppliers of
Artex were still adding white asbestos until 1999.[62]

Prior to the ban, asbestos was widely used in the construction industry in
thousands of materials. Some are judged to be more dangerous than others due
to the amount of asbestos and the material's friable nature. Sprayed coatings,
pipe insulation and Asbestos Insulating Board (AIB) are thought to be the most
dangerous due to their high content of asbestos and friable nature. Many older
buildings built before the late 1990s contain asbestos. In the United States,
there is a minimum standard for asbestos surveys as described by
[ASTM](/wiki/ASTM "ASTM") Standard E 2356–04. In the UK the [Health and Safety
Executive](/wiki/Health_and_Safety_Executive "Health and Safety Executive")
have issued guidance called HSG264 describing how surveys should be completed
although other methods can be used if they can demonstrate they have met the
regulations by other means.[63] The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency
includes some but not all asbestos-contaminated facilities on the Superfund
National Priorities list (NPL). Renovation and demolition of asbestos-
contaminated buildings is subject to EPA [NESHAP](/wiki/NESHAP "NESHAP") and
OSHA Regulations. Asbestos is not a material covered under
[CERCLA](/wiki/CERCLA "CERCLA")'s innocent purchaser defense. In the UK, the
removal and disposal of asbestos and of substances containing it are covered
by the [Control of Asbestos Regulations
2006](/wiki/Control_of_Asbestos_Regulations_2006 "Control of Asbestos
Regulations 2006").[64]

U.S. asbestos consumption hit a peak of 804,000 tons in 1973; world asbestos
demand peaked around 1977, with 25 countries producing nearly 4.8 million
metric tons annually.[65]

In older buildings (e.g. those built prior to 1999 in the UK, before white
asbestos was banned), asbestos may still be present in some areas. Being aware
of asbestos locations reduces the risk of disturbing asbestos.[66]

Removal of asbestos building components can also remove the fire protection
they provide, therefore fire protection substitutes are required for proper
fire protection that the asbestos originally provided.[66][67]

#### Outside Europe and North
America[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Asbestos&action=edit&section=19 "Edit
section: Outside Europe and North America")]

Some countries, such as [India](/wiki/India "India"), Indonesia, China, Russia
and [Brazil](/wiki/Brazil "Brazil"), have continued widespread use of
asbestos. The most common is corrugated asbestos-cement sheets or "A/C sheets"
for roofing and for side walls. Millions of homes, factories, schools or sheds
and shelters continue to use asbestos. Cutting these sheets to size and
drilling holes to receive 'J' bolts to help secure the sheets to roof framing
is done on-site. There has been no significant change in production and use of
A/C sheets in [developing countries](/wiki/Developing_country "Developing
country") following the widespread restrictions in developed
nations[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]. "The largest exporter of asbestos is Russia, which exported 100
million metric tonnes of asbestos.This asbestos is shipped to the nations that
still use this cheap and effective building material. China is the number one
importer of asbestos, using over five-hundred seventy metric tonnes of the
dangerous substance in 2013 alone. China is not the only country that uses
asbestos, Russia, Canada, Brazil and India all use asbestos."[68]

#### 11 September 2001
attacks[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Asbestos&action=edit&section=20 "Edit
section: 11 September 2001 attacks")]

See also: [Health effects arising from the September 11
attacks](/wiki/Health_effects_arising_from_the_September_11_attacks "Health
effects arising from the September 11 attacks")

As [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City")'s [World Trade
Center](/wiki/World_Trade_Center_\(1973-2001\) "World Trade Center
\(1973-2001\)") collapsed following the [September 11
attacks](/wiki/September_11_attacks "September 11 attacks"), [Lower
Manhattan](/wiki/Lower_Manhattan "Lower Manhattan") was blanketed in a mixture
of building debris and combustible materials. This complex mixture gave rise
to the concern that thousands of residents and workers in the area would be
exposed to known hazards in the air and in the dust, such as asbestos, lead,
glass fibers, and pulverized concrete.[69] More than 1,000 tons of asbestos
are thought to have been released into the air following the buildings'
destruction.[70] Inhalation of a mixture of asbestos and other toxicants is
thought to be linked to the unusually high death rate from cancer of emergency
service workers since the disaster.[70] Thousands more are now thought to be
at risk of developing cancer due to this exposure with those who have died so
far being only the "tip of the iceberg".[70] Some commentators have criticised
authorities for using asbestos in the buildings' construction.

In May 2002, after numerous cleanup, dust collection, and air monitoring
activities were conducted outdoors by EPA, other federal agencies, New York
City, and the state of New York, New York City formally requested federal
assistance to clean and test residences in the vicinity of the World Trade
Center site for airborne asbestos.[69]

#### Vermiculite[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Asbestos&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Vermiculite")]

[Vermiculite](/wiki/Vermiculite "Vermiculite") is a hydrated laminar
magnesium-aluminum-iron silicate which resembles [mica](/wiki/Mica "Mica"). It
can be used for many industrial applications and has been used as insulation.
Some deposits of vermiculite have been found to be contaminated with small
amounts of asbestos.[71]

One vermiculite mine operated by [W. R. Grace and
Company](/wiki/W._R._Grace_and_Company "W. R. Grace and Company") in [Libby,
Montana](/wiki/Libby,_Montana "Libby, Montana") exposed workers and community
residents to danger by mining vermiculite contaminated with asbestos,
typically [richterite](/wiki/Richterite "Richterite"),
[winchite](/w/index.php?title=Winchite&action=edit&redlink=1 "Winchite \(page
does not exist\)"), [actinolite](/wiki/Actinolite "Actinolite") or
[tremolite](/wiki/Tremolite "Tremolite").[72] Vermiculite contaminated with
asbestos from the Libby mine was used as insulation in residential and
commercial buildings through Canada and the United States. W. R. Grace and
Company's loose-fill vermiculite was marketed as [Zonolite](/wiki/Zonolite
"Zonolite") but was also used in sprayed-on products such as
[Monokote](/wiki/Monokote "Monokote").

In 1999 the EPA began cleanup efforts in Libby and now the area is a
[Superfund](/wiki/Superfund "Superfund") cleanup area.[73] The EPA has
determined that harmful asbestos is released from the mine as well as through
other activities that disturb soil in the area.[74]

A_laboratory_heat_spreader_made_of_asbestos%2C_over_Teclu_burner.jpg)](/wiki/File:A_laboratory_heat_spreader_made_of_asbestos,_over_Teclu_burner.jpg)

A laboratory [heat spreader](/wiki/Heatproof_mat "Heatproof mat") made of

[Talc](/wiki/Talc "Talc") can sometimes be contaminated with asbestos due to
the proximity of asbestos ore (usually tremolite) in underground talc
deposits.[75] By 1973, US federal law required all talc products to be
asbestos-free,[76] and today there is strict quality control in the production
of talc products, separating cosmetic-grade talc (e.g. talcum powder) from
industrial-grade talc (often used in friction products) has largely eliminated
this issue for consumers.[77]

In 2000, tests in a certified asbestos-testing laboratory found the tremolite
form of amphibole asbestos used to be found in three out of eight popular
brands of children's [crayons](/wiki/Crayon "Crayon") that were made partly
from talc: [Crayola](/wiki/Crayola "Crayola"), Prang, and RoseArt.[78] In
Crayola crayons, the tests found asbestos levels around 0.05% in _Carnation
Pink_ and 2.86% in _Orchid_ ; in Prang crayons, the range was from 0.3% in
_Periwinkle_ to 0.54% in _Yellow_ ; in Rose Art crayons, it was from 0.03% in
_Brown_ to 1.20% in _Orange_. Overall, 32 different types of crayons from
these brands used to contain more than trace amounts of asbestos, and eight
others contained trace amounts. The [Art and Creative Materials
Institute](/wiki/Art_and_Creative_Materials_Institute "Art and Creative
Materials Institute"), a [trade association](/wiki/Trade_association "Trade
association") which tested the safety of crayons on behalf of the makers,
initially insisted the test results must have been incorrect, although they
later said they do not test for asbestos.[78] In May 2000, Crayola said tests
by Richard Lee, a materials analyst whose testimony on behalf of the asbestos
industry has been accepted in lawsuits over 250 times, found its crayons
tested negative for asbestos.[79] In spite of that, in June 2000 Binney &
Smith, the maker of Crayola, and the other makers agreed to stop using talc in
their products, and changed their product formulations in the United
States.[79]

The mining company, R T Vanderbilt Co of [Gouverneur, New
York](/wiki/Gouverneur_\(town\),_New_York "Gouverneur \(town\), New York"),
which supplied the talc to the crayon makers, states that "to the best of our
knowledge and belief" there is no asbestos in its talc.[80] However media
reports claim that the [United States Mine Safety and Health
Administration](/wiki/United_States_Mine_Safety_and_Health_Administration
"United States Mine Safety and Health Administration") (MSHA) had found
asbestos in four talc samples tested in 2000.[78] The Assistant Secretary for
Mine Safety and Health subsequently wrote to the news reporter, stating that
"In fact, the abbreviation ND (non detect) in the laboratory report –
indicates no asbestos fibers actually were found in the samples",[81] and
multiple studies by both mineral studies
laboratories[82][83][84][85][86][87][88][89][90] and biological cell
studies[91][92][93] do not report asbestos. These findings have been rejected
by other health reports and studies which advocate a "same as" asbestos
risk.[94][95]

All types of asbestos fibers are known to cause serious health hazards in
humans.[96][97][98] Amosite and crocidolite are considered the most hazardous
asbestos fiber types;[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] however, chrysotile asbestos has also produced
tumors in animals and is a recognized cause of asbestosis and malignant
mesothelioma in humans,[99] and mesothelioma has been observed in people who
were occupationally exposed to chrysotile, family members of the
occupationally exposed, and residents who lived close to asbestos factories
and mines.[100]

During the 1980s and again in the 1990s it was suggested at times that the
process of making asbestos cement could "neutralize" the asbestos, either via
chemical processes or by causing cement to attach to the fibers and changing
their physical size; subsequent studies showed that this was untrue, and that
decades-old asbestos cement, when broken, releases asbestos fibers identical
to those found in nature, with no detectable alteration.[101]

Exposure to asbestos in the form of fibers is always considered dangerous.
Working with, or exposure to, material that is [friable](/wiki/Friable
"Friable"), or materials or works that could cause release of loose asbestos
fibers, is considered high risk. In general, people who become ill from
inhaling asbestos have been regularly exposed in a job where they worked
directly with the material.

The most common diseases associated with chronic exposure to asbestos are
[asbestosis](/wiki/Asbestosis "Asbestosis") and
[mesothelioma](/wiki/Mesothelioma "Mesothelioma").[102]

## Substitutes for asbestos in
construction[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Asbestos&action=edit&section=25 "Edit
section: Substitutes for asbestos in construction")]

[Fiberglass](/wiki/Glass_wool "Glass wool") insulation was invented in 1938
and is now the most commonly used type of [insulation
material](/wiki/Building_insulation_materials "Building insulation
materials"). The safety of this material has also been called into question
due to similarities in material structure.[103] However, the [International
Agency for Research on
Cancer](/wiki/International_Agency_for_Research_on_Cancer "International
Agency for Research on Cancer") removed fiberglass from its list of possible
human carcinogens in 2001[104] and a scientific review article from 2011
claimed epidemiology data was inconsistent and concluded that the IARC's
decision to downgrade the carcinogenic potential of fiberglass was valid
(however, this study was funded by sponsored research contract from the North
American Insulation Manufacturer’s Association).[105]

In 1978, a highly texturized fiberglass fabric was invented by [Bal
Dixit](/wiki/Bal_Dixit "Bal Dixit"), called [Zetex](/wiki/Zetex_\(fabric\)
"Zetex \(fabric\)"). This fabric is lighter than asbestos, but offers the same
bulk, thickness, hand, feel, and abrasion resistance as asbestos. The
fiberglass was texturized to eliminate some of the problems that arise with
fiberglass, such as poor abrasion resistance and poor seam strength.[106]

In Europe, [mineral wool](/wiki/Mineral_wool "Mineral wool") and [glass
wool](/wiki/Glass_wool "Glass wool") are the main insulators in houses.

Many companies that produced asbestos-cement products that were reinforced
with asbestos fibers have developed products incorporating organic fibers. One
such product was known as "[Eternit](/wiki/Eternit "Eternit")" and another
"Everite" now use "[Nutec](/wiki/Nutec "Nutec")" fibers which consist of
organic fibers, [portland cement](/wiki/Portland_cement "Portland cement") and
[silica](/wiki/Silica "Silica"). [Cement-bonded wood fiber](/wiki/Cement-
bonded_wood_fiber "Cement-bonded wood fiber") is another substitute. Stone
fibers are used in gaskets and friction materials.

Another potential fiber is [polybenzimidazole](/wiki/Polybenzimidazole
"Polybenzimidazole") or PBI fiber. [Polybenzimidazole
fiber](/wiki/Polybenzimidazole_fiber "Polybenzimidazole fiber") is a
[synthetic fiber](/wiki/Synthetic_fiber "Synthetic fiber") with a high
[melting point](/wiki/Melting_point "Melting point") of 760 °C (1,400 °F) that
also does not ignite. Because of its exceptional thermal and chemical
stability, it is often used by [fire departments](/wiki/Fire_departments "Fire
departments") and [space agencies](/wiki/Space_agencies "Space agencies").

## Recycling and
disposal[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Asbestos&action=edit&section=26 "Edit
section: Recycling and disposal")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/AsbestosContainment.JPG/220px-
AsbestosContainment.JPG)](/wiki/File:AsbestosContainment.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:AsbestosContainment.JPG "Enlarge")

Old [Wailuku](/wiki/Wailuku "Wailuku") Post Office sealed off for [asbestos
removal](/wiki/Asbestos_removal "Asbestos removal")

Asbestos alternatives for industrial use include sleeves, rope, tape, fabric,
textiles and [insulation batt materials](/wiki/Insulation_batt_materials
"Insulation batt materials") made from [fiberglass](/wiki/Fiberglass
"Fiberglass") and silica.

In most developed countries, asbestos is typically disposed of as [hazardous
waste](/wiki/Hazardous_waste "Hazardous waste") in [landfill
sites](/wiki/Landfill_site "Landfill site").

The [demolition](/wiki/Demolition "Demolition") of buildings containing large
amounts of asbestos based materials pose particular problems for builders and
property developers – such buildings often have to be deconstructed piece by
piece, or the asbestos has to be painstakingly removed before the structure
can be razed by mechanical or explosive means. One such example is the [Red
Road Flats](/wiki/Red_Road_Flats "Red Road Flats") in [Glasgow](/wiki/Glasgow
"Glasgow"), Scotland which used huge amounts of asbestos cement board for wall
panelling – here British health and safety regulations stipulate that asbestos
material has to be removed to a landfill site via an approved route at certain
times of the day in specially adapted vehicles.

Asbestos can be recycled by transforming it into harmless [silicate
glass](/wiki/Silicate_glass "Silicate glass"). A process of thermal
decomposition at 1000–1250 °C produces a mixture of non-hazardous silicate
phases, and at temperatures above 1250 °C it produces silicate glass.[107]
Microwave thermal treatment can be used in an industrial manufacturing process
to transform asbestos and asbestos-containing waste into porcelain stoneware
tiles, porous single-fired wall tiles, and ceramic bricks.[108]

The combination of [oxalic acid](/wiki/Oxalic_acid "Oxalic acid") with
[ultrasound](/wiki/Ultrasound "Ultrasound") fully degrades chrysotile asbestos
fibers.[109]
